ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Re: Does the client contribute to the RESTfulness of an application?

"A client not obeying the rules does not necessarily remove all benefits of=

REST for the server, though it can if it is the ONLY client."

The more i =
think about this, the more I realize that is probably not
entirely true. Th=
e client not being RESTful can remove some benefits but
not all. For exampl=
e as long as the server implements GET in an
idemponent/safe manner then th=
at means the response can safely be cached.
Nothing the client does can pre=
vent that fact.

However, if the client couples to the uri space rather tha=
n following
hypermedia AND it is the only client, or it is one of the predo=
minantly
used clients then it can impact the ability of the server to evolv=
e as if
the server changes the uri scheme, a significant set of users are s=
hut out
until the client is updated.

On Sat, Mar 10, 2012 at 1:21 PM, Glen=
n Block <glenn.block@...> wrote:

> Thanks for the explanation Willia=
m.
>
> Here's my tough take aways on this convo:
>
>    - A RESTful system =
has a shared set of responsibilities between client
>    and server. To tru=
ly realize the benefits of REST both client and server
>    have to be good=
 citizens.
>    - The server is the critical path. It's responsibility is t=
o expose
>    resources in a manner that is consistent with adhering to the=
 constraints.
>    That means it sticks to the uniform interface (headers, =
media types),
>    supports caching, uses hypermedia etc.
>    - The client=
 must also adhere to REST constraints. If it does not,
>    then the overal=
l benefits of REST are not achieved within that system. It's
>    responsib=
ility is to consume resources in a RESTful manner, i.e. use the
>    unifor=
m interface, consumes hypermedia, obeys caching requirements, etc.
>    - A=
 client not obeying the rules does not necessarily remove all
>    benefits=
 of REST for the server, though it can if it is the ONLY client.
>    - Not=
 enough emphasis is put on this division of responsibilities when
>    talk=
ing about REST.
>
> Thoughts?
>
> Thanks
> Glenn
>
>
> On Sat, Mar 10, 2012=
 at 1:06 PM, William Martinez Pomares <
> wmartinez@...> wrote:
>
=
>> **
>>
>>
>> Fine then, Glenn, here it is plain answer:
>>
>> a. Yes if y=
ou define RESTFulness as a badge that certifies you follow the
>> rules. Ye=
s, you can earn that badge only in your server and forget about
>> the clie=
nt.
>>
>> b. NO, if you define RESTFulness as the achievement of the expect=
ed
>> quality properties you seek for when using REST. And that NO is becau=
se the
>> rules are made to achieve a way of interaction between the compon=
ents, and
>> one of those components is the client.
>>
>> In other words, c=
lient matters.
>>
>> As I had been posting here, one component may not beha=
ve by the rules,
>> but if that is free license the architect is aware of a=
nd it is reasonable
>> so that the impact will not break the business goals=
, that is fine. But if
>> you need a system where clients behave correctly,=
 and you don't control the
>> clients, then your architecture must have con=
trols and policy enforcement
>> to avoid those spoiled clients from ruining=
 you day. If not, your system
>> will not get to its goal and it will be a =
failure, even if your server is
>> made by the REST book.
>>
>> REST stops =
when it defines the constrains and promises quality
>> properties, but life=
 goes on, and the rest of the system is still to be
>> constructed. Having =
just one server following REST rules is just one step.
>> And let me clarif=
y this: It should not be part of the server's job to
>> assure the client i=
s working as it should. It may help, but we can have
>> several layers that=
 can add controls and enforce policies. There is far
>> more in an system t=
han just one server and one client.
>>
>> Finally: I feel the discussion co=
nfuses an App, with a Server, with a
>> System, with a API. When we talk ab=
out a server doing its part, sounds like
>> we are talking about an API. Is=
 it that? Yes, we can expose a REST like
>> API, but then we need a client =
to consume it. A system is something far
>> more complex, where all compone=
nts, including clients, may affect other
>> components. Butterfly effect, t=
hat is called.
>>
>> Well, this was not a short and sweet answer, and I fee=
l I'm repeating
>> myself here. But it is truly a more deep discussion than=
 just earning a
>> badge.
>>
>> Cheers
>>
>> William.
>>
>>

discuss@yahoogroups.com, Glenn Block <glenn.block@...> wrote:
>> >
>> > My =
point was that this is not a contest of who can earn the REST badge.
>> The=

>> > question I am seeking clarification on is whether or not the
>> RESTf=
ulness of
>> > a system is confined to the server or not / what defines the=
 scope of
>> the
>> > system.
>> >
>> > My understanding up until now is th=
at REST really is confined to how the
>> > server is implemented and does n=
ot directly include the client However
>> I am
>> > questioning that unders=
tanding. The discertation clearly speaks about
>> both
>> > client and serv=
er components.
>> >
>> > So my only goal is to get more understanding. The =
result can impact how
>> I
>> > speak/educate about REST and also how I bui=
ld RESTful systems. For
>> example
>> > as Mike mentioned, you can create o=
paque uris to prevent the client from
>> > coupling to the uri space.

 guess. Which is 100% valid, but the

ect what you were actually asking, I

"A client not obeying the rules does not necessarily remove all benefi=
ts of REST for the server, though it can if it is the ONLY client."<di=
v><br></div><div>The more i think about this, the more I realize that is pr=
obably not entirely true. The client not being RESTful can remove some bene=
fits but not all. For example as long as the server implements GET in an id=
emponent/safe manner then that means the response can safely be cached. Not=
hing the client does can prevent that fact.</div>
<div><br></div><div>Howev=
er, if the client couples to the uri space rather than following hypermedia=
 AND it is the only client, or it is one of the predominantly used clients =
then it can impact the ability of the server to evolve as if the server cha=
nges the uri scheme, a significant set of users are shut out until the clie=
nt is updated.</div>
<div><br></div><div><div class=3D"gmail_quote">On Sat,=
 Mar 10, 2012 at 1:21 PM, Glenn Block <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a href=3D"mail=
to:glenn.block@...">glenn.block@...</a>></span> wrote:<br><b=
lockquote class=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px =
#ccc solid;padding-left:1ex">
Thanks for the explanation William.<div><br><=
/div><div>Here's my tough take aways on this convo:</div><div><ul><li>A=
 RESTful system has a shared set of responsibilities between client and ser=
ver. To truly realize the benefits of REST both client and server have to b=
e good citizens.</li>

<li>The server is the critical path. It's respon=
sibility is to expose resources in a manner that is consistent with adherin=
g to the constraints. That means it sticks to the uniform interface (header=
s, media types), supports caching, uses hypermedia etc.</li>

<li>The clien=
t must also adhere to REST constraints. If it does not, then the overall be=
nefits of REST are not achieved within that system. It's responsibility=
 is to consume resources in a RESTful manner, i.e. use the uniform interfac=
e, consumes hypermedia, obeys caching requirements, etc.</li>

<li>A client=
 not obeying the rules does not necessarily remove all benefits of REST for=
 the server, though it can if it is the ONLY client.</li><li>Not enough emp=
hasis is put on this division of responsibilities when talking about REST.<=
/li>

</ul><div>Thoughts?</div><div><br></div><div>Thanks</div></div><span =
class=3D"HOEnZb"><font color=3D"#888888"><div>Glenn</div></font></span><div=
 class=3D"HOEnZb"><div class=3D"h5"><div><br><br><div class=3D"gmail_quote"=
>On Sat, Mar 10, 2012 at 1:06 PM, William Martinez Pomares <span dir=3D"ltr=
"><<a href=3D"mailto:wmartinez@..." target=3D"_blank">wmartinez=
@...</a>></span> wrote:<br>

<blockquote class=3D"gmail_quote" =
style=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px #ccc solid;padding-left:1ex">


=
<u></u>










<div>
<span>=A0</span>


<div>
  <div>


    <div>
      =

      
      <p>Fine then, Glenn, here it is plain answer:<br>
<br>
a. Yes=
 if you define RESTFulness as a badge that certifies you follow the rules. =
Yes, you can earn that badge only in your server and forget about the clien=
t.<br>
<br>
b. NO, if you define RESTFulness as the achievement of the expe=
cted quality properties you seek for when using REST. And that NO is becaus=
e the rules are made to achieve a way of interaction between the components=
, and one of those components is the client. <br>


<br>
In other words, cl=
ient matters.<br>
<br>
As I had been posting here, one component may not be=
have by the rules, but if that is free license the architect is aware of an=
d it is reasonable so that the impact will not break the business goals, th=
at is fine. But if you need a system where clients behave correctly, and yo=
u don't control the clients, then your architecture must have controls =
and policy enforcement to avoid those spoiled clients from ruining you day.=
 If not, your system will not get to its goal and it will be a failure, eve=
n if your server is made by the REST book. <br>


<br>
REST stops when it d=
efines the constrains and promises quality properties, but life goes on, an=
d the rest of the system is still to be constructed. Having just one server=
 following REST rules is just one step. And let me clarify this: It should =
not be part of the server's job to assure the client is working as it s=
hould. It may help, but we can have several layers that can add controls an=
d enforce policies. There is far more in an system than just one server and=
 one client.<br>


<br>
Finally: I feel the discussion confuses an App, wit=
h a Server, with a System, with a API. When we talk about a server doing it=
s part, sounds like we are talking about an API. Is it that? Yes, we can ex=
pose a REST like API, but then we need a client to consume it. A system is =
something far more complex, where all components, including clients, may af=
fect other components. Butterfly effect, that is called.<br>


<br>
Well, t=
his was not a short and sweet answer, and I feel I'm repeating myself h=
ere. But it is truly a more deep discussion than just earning a badge.<br>
=
<br>
Cheers<br>
<br>
William.</p><div><br>
<br>

g that understanding. The discertation clearly speaks about both<br>

lient and server components.<br>
> <br>
> So my only goal is to get m=
ore understanding. The result can impact how I<br>

 REST and also how I build RESTful systems. For example<br>
> as Mike me=
ntioned, you can create opaque uris to prevent the client from<br>
> cou=
pling to the uri space.<br>
